Authors:
Lisa Carol Grubisha, Nicholas J Dowie, Christina Hazard,
Steven L Miller, Thomas R Horton, Steven M Trowbridge, Matthew R
Klooster
Title:
Rhizopogon kretzerae sp. nov.: the rare fungal symbiont in
the tripartite system with pinedrops (Pterospora andromedea) and eastern
white pine (Pinus strobus) in eastern North America known only from
ectomycorrhizal roots.
Keywords:
Rhizopogon kretzerae, mycoheterotrophy, Pterospora
andromedea, endangered species
Abstract:
Pterospora andromedea is a mycoheterotrophic plant with a
disjunct distribution found primarily in western North America with a
few rare to endangered populations in eastern North America. Pterospora
forms obligate ectomycorrhizal symbioses with four fungal species in
Rhizopogon subgenus Amylopogon, including an undescribed eastern
Rhizopogon species. There are no known sporocarp records of this
putative new Rhizopogon species. Thus, we provide the first species
description for Rhizopogon kretzerae sp. nov. based on phylogenetic
analyses and nucleotide divergence of the nuclear ribosomal Internal
Transcribed Spacer region (ITS). Maximum likelihood, maximum parsimony
and Bayesian analyses and nucleotide divergence estimates of Rhizopogon
ITS sequences from Pterospora roots from Quebec, Michigan, New York, and
New Hampshire combined with ITS sequences of R. subgenus Amylopogon
species type collections suggest R. kretzerae is a sister-group to R.
salebrosus. An absence of shared mutations, two informative sequence
gaps, and 12 fixed nucleotide differences differentiate R. kretzerae and
R. salebrosus. Furthermore, ITS sequences of 40 Pterospora root samples
from five populations in Quebec Province provided the first record of
the distribution of R. kretzerae, a rare to endangered species, in
eastern Canada. Rhizopogon kretzerae is the first record of a Rhizopogon
subgenus Amylopogon species from eastern North America.
